description.p: Although the invention has been described with reference to preferred embodiments and specific examples, it will readily be appreciated by those of ordinary skill in the art that many modifications and adaptions of the invention are possible without departure from the spirit and scope of the invention as claimed hereinafter. For example, while the processes according to the present invention have been described in terms of recovering gold from refractory sulfide or refractory carbonaceous sulfide ores, the processes are equally applicable to other precious metals found in these ores such as silver and platinum. Similarly, the process according to the present invention may, as one skilled in the art would readily recognize, be used to biooxidize sulfide concentrates from metal sulfide ores such as chalcopyrite and sphalorite.

claim.claim-text: 1. A method of biooxidizing metal sulfide particles from a sulfide ore using a nonstirred bioreactor to liberate metal values of interest, comprising:a. obtaining a concentrate of the metal sulfide particles;b. coating the surface of a plurality of coarse substrates with the concentrate of metal sulfide particles;c. forming a heap using the plurality of coated substrates; andd. biooxidizing the metal sulfide particles on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates.

2. A method according to claim 1, wherein the material used for said plurality of coarse substrates is at least one material selected from the group consisting of coarse ore particles containing metal sulfide particles, lava rock, gravel, and rock containing mineral carbonate.
3. A method according to claim 1, wherein the amount of concentrate coated onto the plurality of coarse substrates is from approximately 10% to approximately 30%.

4. A method according to claim 1, further comprising the steps of:e. breaking the heap down after the metal sulfide particles coated on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates are biooxidized to a desired degree;f. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates; andg. repeating steps b-d using the plurality of coarse substrates.
5. A method according to claim 1, wherein the plurality of coarse substrates comprise coarse ore particles that contain metal sulfide particles.
6. A method according to claim 5, wherein the coarse ore particles have a nominal particle size greater than or equal to about 0.6 cm and less than or equal to about 2.5 cm.

7. A method according to claim 5, further comprising the steps of:e. breaking the heap down after the metal sulfide particles coated on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates are biooxidized to a desired degree;f. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates;g. grinding the plurality of coarse substrates to a particle size sufficient to permit the separation of metal sulfide particles therefrom;h. producing a second concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the plurality of ground coarse substrates;i. coating a second plurality of coarse substrates with the second concentrate;j. forming a second heap using the second plurality of coated substrates; andk. biooxidizing the second concentrate of metal sulfide particles.
8. A method according to claim 7, wherein the coarse ore particles also contain mineral carbonate.
9. A method according to claim 1, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least 20 weight % of metal sulfides.
10. A method according to claim 1, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 40 weight % metal sulfides.
11. A method according to claim 1, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 70 weight % metal sulfides.
12. A method according to claim 1, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises between 40 and 80 weight % metal sulfides.
13. A method according to claim 1, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 38 μm and less than or equal to 250 μm.
14. A method according to claim 1, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 106 μm and less than or equal to 75 μm.

15. A method of recovering precious metal values from precious metal bearing refractory sulfide ore using a nonstirred bioreactor, the method comprising the steps of:a. producing a concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the refractory sulfide ore;b coating the surface of a plurality of coarse substrates with the concentrate of metal sulfide particles;c. forming a heap using the plurality of coated substrates;d. biooxidizing the metal sulfide particles on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates;e. contacting the biooxidized metal sulfide particles with a precious metal lixiviant to thereby dissolve precious metal values from the biooxidized metal sulfide particles; andf. recovering precious metal values from the lixiviant.
16. A method according to claim 15, wherein the lixiviant is selected from the group consisting of thiourea and cyanide.

17. A method according to claim 15, further comprising the steps of:g. breaking the heap down after the metal sulfide particles coated on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates are biooxidized to a desired degree; andh. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates prior to contacting with the lixiviant.
18. A method according to claim 15, wherein the precious metal recovered is at least one selected from the group consisting of silver, gold and platinum.

19. A method according to claim 15, wherein the material used for said plurality of coarse substrates is at least one material selected from the group consisting of coarse ore particles containing metal sulfide particles, lava rock, gravel, and rock containing mineral carbonate.
20. A method according to claim 15, wherein the amount of concentrate coated onto the plurality of coarse substrates is from approximately 10% to approximately 30%.
21. A method according to claim 15, wherein the plurality of coarse substrates comprise coarse refractory sulfide ore particles having precious metal values occluded within metal sulfide particles.
22. A method according to claim 21, wherein the coarse ore particles have a nominal particle size greater than or equal to about 0.6 cm and less than or equal to about 2.5 cm.

23. A method according to claim 21, further comprising the steps of:g. breaking the heap down after the metal sulfide particles coated on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates are biooxidized to a desired degree;h. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates prior to contacting with the lixiviant;i. grinding the plurality of coarse substrates to a particle size sufficient to permit the separation of the metal sulfide particles therefrom;j. producing a second concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the plurality of ground coarse substrates;k. coating a second plurality of coarse substrates with the second concentrate;l. forming a second heap using the second plurality of coated substrates;m. biooxidizing the second concentrate of metal sulfide particles;n. contacting the biooxidized second concentrate with the precious metal lixiviant to thereby dissolve precious metal values from the biooxidized second concentrate; ando. recovering precious metal values dissolved from the second concentrate from the lixiviant.
24. A method according to claim 23, wherein the coarse ore particles originate from the refractory sulfide ore used to produce the concentrate.
25. A method according to claim 21, wherein the coarse ore particles also contain mineral carbonate.

26. A method according to claim 15, further comprising the steps of:breaking the heap down after the metal sulfide particles coated on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates are biooxidized to a desired degree;h. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates prior to contacting with the lixiviant; andi. repeating steps b-f using the plurality of coarse substrates.
27. A method according to claim 15, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 20 weight % metal sulfides.
28. A method according to claim 15, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 40 weight % metal sulfides.
29. A method according to claim 15, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 70 weight % metal sulfides.
30. A method according to claim 15, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises between 40 and 80 weight % metal sulfides.
31. A method according to claim 15, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 38 μm and less than or equal to 250 μm.
32. A method according to claim 15, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 106 μm and less than or equal to 75 μm.

33. A method of recovering precious metal values from precious metal bearing refractory sulfide ore using a nonstirred bioreactor, the method comprising the steps of:a. producing a concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the refractory sulfide ore;b. coating the surface of a plurality of coarse substrates with the concentrate of metal sulfide particles;c. placing the plurality of coated substrates in a tank;d. biooxidizing the metal sulfide particles on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates;e. contacting the biooxidized metal sulfide particles with a precious metal lixiviant to thereby dissolve precious metal values from the biooxidized metal sulfide particles; andf. recovering precious metal values from the lixiviant.
34. A method according to claim 33, wherein the lixiviant is selected from the group consisting of thiourea and cyanide.

35. A method according to claim 33, further comprising the step of:g. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates prior to contacting with the lixiviant.

36. A method according to claim 35, wherein the method of separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates comprises filling the tank with an aqueous solution and then rapidly draining the tank to thereby carry the biooxidized metal sulfide particles out of the tank in the aqueous solution.
37. A method according to claim 33, wherein the precious metal recovered is at least one selected from the group consisting of silver, gold and platinum.

38. A method according to claim 33, wherein the material used for said plurality of coarse substrates is at least one material selected from the group consisting of coarse ore particles containing metal sulfide particles, lava rock, gravel, and rock containing mineral carbonate.
39. A method according to claim 33, wherein the amount of concentrate coated onto the plurality of coarse substrates is from approximately 10% to approximately 30%.
40. A method according to claim 33, wherein the plurality of coarse substrates comprise coarse refractory sulfide ore particles having precious metal values occluded within metal sulfide particles.
41. A method according to claim 40, wherein the coarse ore particles have a nominal particle size greater than or equal to about 0.6 cm and less than or equal to about 2.5 cm.

42. A method according to claim 40, further comprising the steps of:g. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates;h. grinding the plurality of coarse substrates to a particle size sufficient to permit the separation of metal sulfide particles therefrom;i. producing a second concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the plurality of ground coarse substrates;j. coating a second plurality of coarse substrates with the second concentrate;k. forming a second heap using the second plurality of coated substrates;l. biooxidizing the second concentrate of metal sulfide particles;m. contacting the biooxidized second concentrate with the precious metal lixiviant to thereby dissolve precious metal values from the biooxidized second concentrate; andn. recovering precious metal values dissolved from the second concentrate from the lixiviant.
43. A method according to claim 42, wherein the coarse ore particles originate from the refractory sulfide ore used to produce the concentrate.
44. A method according to claim 42, wherein the coarse ore particles includes a carbonate mineral component.

45. A method according to claim 42, wherein the method of separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates comprises filling the tank with an aqueous solution and then rapidly draining the tank to thereby carry the biooxidized metal sulfide particles out of the tank in the aqueous solution.

46. A method according to claim 33, further comprising the steps of:g. separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates prior to contacting with the lixiviant; andh. repeating steps b-f using the plurality of coarse substrates.

47. A method according to claim 46, wherein the method of separating the biooxidized metal sulfide particles from the plurality of coarse substrates comprises filling the tank with an aqueous solution and then rapidly draining the tank to thereby carry the biooxidized metal sulfide particles out of the tank in the aqueous solution.
48. A method according to claim 33, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 20 weight % metal sulfides.
49. A method according to claim 33, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 40 weight % metal sulfides.
50. A method according to claim 33, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises at least about 70 weight % metal sulfides.
51. A method according to claim 33, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises between 40 and 80 weight % metal sulfides.
52. A method according to claim 33, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 38 μm and less than or equal to 250 μm.
53. A method according to claim 33, wherein the metal sulfide particles in the concentrate have a particle size that is greater than or equal to 106 μm and less than or equal to 75 μm.

54. A method of recovering metal values from a sulfide mineral ore using a nonstirred bioreactor, the method comprising the steps of:a. producing a concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the sulfide mineral ore;b. coating the surface of a plurality of coarse substrates with the concentrate of metal sulfide particles;c. forming a heap using the plurality of coated substrates;d. biooxidizing the metal sulfide particles on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates to thereby cause the production of a bioleachate off solution; ande. recovering the desired metal values from the bioleachate off solution.
55. A method according to claim 54, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises particles of copper sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is copper.

56. A method according to claim 54, wherein the method of recovering copper from the bioleachate off solution comprises at least one process selected from the group consisting of solvent extraction, copper cementation, and electrowinning.
57. A method according to claim 54, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises zinc sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is zinc.
58. A method according to claim 54, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises nickel sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is nickel.

59. A method of recovering metal values from a sulfide mineral ore using a nonstirred bioreactor, the method comprising the steps of:a. producing a concentrate of metal sulfide particles from the sulfide mineral ore;b. coating the surface of a plurality of coarse substrates with the concentrate of metal sulfide particles;c. placing the plurality of coated substrates in a tank;d. biooxidizing the metal sulfide particles on the surface of the plurality of coarse substrates to thereby cause the production of a bioleachate off solution; ande. recovering the desired metal values from the bioleachate off solution.
60. A method according to claim 59, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises particles of copper sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is copper.

61. A method according to claim 59 wherein the method of recovering copper from the bioleachate off solution comprises at least one process selected from the group consisting of solvent extraction, copper cementation, and electrowinning.
62. A method according to claim 59, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises zinc sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is zinc.
63. A method according to claim 59, wherein the concentrate of metal sulfide particles comprises nickel sulfide minerals and the metal recovered is nickel.
